title: Building Multilingual Web Sites with Joomla! the Leading Open Source CMS
segmentation: So after hearing about Drupal, I'm here to talk about Joomla specifically about building multilingual websites with Joomla.
I'm so full.
So my name is.
Ryan team, am I?
I'm not a developer, I'm not coder, not designer, I am.
One of the one of the cofounders of Jumla.
I'm based in the UK, although it does seem most of the time I live.
British Airways seat 10 C. Because I'm really lucky.
Then I get to do the one thing that I.
Love which is to travel the world and talk.
About jungler.
So Joomla is a CMS, no it.
Not SMS Joomla.
And other systems like it are often called content management systems.
I don't believe that it really is a content management system, it's really.
It's a tool to help you build websites.
And to help you manage websites.
Jim.
It is multilingual and it's also.
Multinational
Junior is the law.
Not just of the open source EMS.
That's the ones oops, I said.
ACMS again, so it's.
On Joomla is open, so.
Horse it's complete.
Community managed it.
Has no employees.
No corporate backer.
It's the only one of the big open source.
Website creation software that can say that.
And right from day one in 2005, languages mattered to us.
The name junior itself is actually a Swahili word, which means altogether and it's been a founding principle of jungler that it will work wherever possible with every language that's available.
So right now today you can install jungler in over 65 languages.
Now in the Google presentation this morning was about 65 languages.

East is.
Is Klingon is great for access denied and no, but it's not very good for yes.

Some of those are done by teams.
Some of them are done by individuals, it really.
Depends on the language.
Each.
With junior itself, we can actually install and run jumbler in your own language.
That's really important because.
You don't need to know English.
Lots of systems.
Let you create content in other languages.
But you still need to know English in order to create that content.
Yeah, if you install one of the language packs for Joomla, which you do even the installation in your own language, then you never need to know a single word of English.
Just as a side thing, Ian Dash GB is the default language of jungler.
I worked really hard to ensure that color is spelt with a U.
But it's not required by anybody.
So you can quite happily run jungler in any language in any single language, and that's great, and for most people that's all they want.
They just want to run their websites in their own language.
But what about multi lingual?
What about running it in?
More than one language?
Well again, that's not.
Problem either.
We see.
Install additional languages.
And then we tag our contents.
Translate
Content and then we make this.
Sociation between the translations.
One thing we did learn fairly early on is that not all content needs to be translated.
You sometimes don't want to translate the individual piece of content, but you do want to translate the category.
So the quickest example I can think of is if you're doing a website about children's poetry.

The example poets that you're going to choose in the English language will be very different to the example poets that you would choose in the French language or German, so you don't want to translate those individual articles, but you do want to translate the actual menu links, so that's more localization than translation.
So in that case you would just tag associate the menu item or the category and not the individual article.
You don't need necessarily to translate all contents.
So Joomla 3, which is our latest release it.
The first major CMS.
Set it again.
Jim.
Is the fur.
First major website creation software that out of the box is mobile ready.
What?
I mean by that I mean that you can build one site and it works on all sizes of device.
Well, that's a phone, a tablet, a desktop computer, a TV, or whatever knew size device comes out.
Joomla three is responsive out of the box.
No extra sites, no m.domain.com, no wap.domain.com.
If you're a bit older, it's all one website.
It's all delivered in the same optimal way for the size of your device.
Rather than trying some life demos, there's just two websites I chose which if you can get an Internet connection, you can go to this.
Just to that I randomly selected.
This one is in Swedish, English and Russian I believe.
I think the furniture store in Sweden.
And this is.
A hotel chain in the Blair account in Madeira which is in Spanish Russian.
I think French and English, and as you can see from there the website is 1 website.
It's not multiple websites here, it's just one single website and it works happily on all the sizes of devices and hopefully on whatever the new form factors the manufacturers come up with next.
So Joomla itself is designed when you install it for the first time.
It's designed so that you can actually build your website.
It's got all the tools there that most people need, but it's also we also acknowledge that you want to extend.
You want to add new functionality, new features, and that's incredibly simple to do as well.
You can either do that with.
Off the shelf extensions.
Oil you can get custom code.
It's a published API, it's all open source, lots of tutorials and information, and of course being open source.
There's no real.
Directions on what you can actually do.
So of course those extensions, those add-ons they also need to be translated as well.
Now, some of those extensions might be written by a company in Spain, or the amount were written by an individual sitting in a small office in Vietnam.
They all need to be translated because the interface itself needs to be translated.
Now, if that developer doesn't have access to a translator, then there's a community group that created that set up called Open translators.org.
They're using a service called trans effects to manage their translations, and this group of people working together will translate anybody's junior extension.
So currently there working in 81 different languages.
There is over 1000.
Translators.
That's nice.
Almost 95,000.
Things that are translating.
And that's over 5,000,000 words.
So even.
If you take Gimmler, which is available in your language and then install an extension, you can get that extension translated into your language as well.

And of course, even if that's not good enough for you, or it's not quite right or you don't like the specific translation, perhaps the developer has used the word go and you'd prefer the words start for your button.
Then built into every Joomla website is a language manager which lets you override and customize the individual language strings of the interfaces.
So whichever option you need to do, it's all there for you.
So talk about extending.
Jumlah that's giving you the user of.
Website the owner of the website, Empowerment to control it to in.
And sure, own websites.

1000 extras for the current release.
If I wanted to count each one of them for each version that they're available for, I would have a lot bigger number if I wanted to count the ones for the old versions.
I have a lot.
Bigger number is 6000 for the current release of jungler.

I think for people building multilingual websites.

Name?

It's got the all the keywords there.

So perhaps it's.

But doesn't separate domain names mean separate websites?
Will no, it doesn't.
For example with this.

Looking here, it works so that recognizes within the German system and instead of re when you switch to the Spanish language or your detective 'cause of your browser language is being a Spanish speaker instead of being redirected to learnjoomla3.com/E S, you're redirected to a user john.com.
Which makes more sense?
The second example, and we've heard quite block talk about translation management systems, and Pedro said in his presentation that their stuff is great.
Was it half a million words?
For real time for over that for real time.
OK, so it's suitable for you from the presentation suitable for large websites and large clients.
So in the Journal.
Told a lot of people who are wanting to own multilingual websites.
They're not in that position.
They're not running huge enormous websites, so we have an ability to add a translation management system directly into Joomla.
It's called josetta.
Here is the what the typical dashboard would look like.
Currently it's showing all the languages enabled on that specific website.
You could use the built in administrator rules to only give access to the ones that need translating in Spanish to the Spanish speaking user and the French to the French speaking translator.
Or you could just keep it all the same.
It will show you how many items need translating, what percentage translation there at, etc all within the native Joomla content types.
Here we can see a screen.
All of what the actual translation interface looks like.
It's actually just in the process of being updated, so it's a little bit out of date that screen we can see at the top.
We can set the percentage of translation down the left hand side.
We can see the original language version.
In this case it's English, but of course it could be whatever is your native language and on the right hand side we see the proposed new translation.

You will see there's an option there to quickly copy across from left to right is also an option there, which called suggests that suggests 1 uses the Bing Translate API, and it is only there as a suggestion because you know machine translations.
Not going to be 100% yet, but it's there as a suggestion and then finally up at the top right.
You can also, if you already manually created the article in another language, you can translate it across.
So Jim.
It's not just about.
Being open source, it's.
About empowering the site owner to have full control over their own websites.
Not having to go outside.
It's their website after all.
Sorry.
Little bit scared Thunder and lightning.

It's they should be in complete control of it and that's one of the overriding things we believe in Joomla is that it empowers you to do that.
So that slide has not shown up at all.
It should above that says thank you very much.

I'm here for.
Two days there's just one condition.
If you do want to ask me a question.
Can I have a coffee please?
